questions.text: Which of the following statements about inverted papilloma is false?

choices.text: Arises from the lateral wall of nose
Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis

questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma is more common in males.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosed with inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of his condition?

choices.text: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up

questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy.

Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection.

Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas.

Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity?
questions.solution: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, seen in about 80% of cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as nose picker’s carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasal cavity arising from the nasal septum is called nose picker’s cancer.

Option A: Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma.

Option B: Basal cell carcinoma is also known as rodent ulcer.

Option D: Esthesioneuroblastoma is also known as olfactory neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 15-year-old presented with a cherry red, polypoidal mass detected on anterior rhinoscopy. Biopsy of the mass suggested that it originated from the olfactory neural epithelium. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma. It arises from the olfactory epithelium of the upper third of the nose.

Related Pearl: Esthesioneuroblastoma

Esthesioneuroblastoma is known as olfactory neuroblastoma or olfactory placode tumor.

It arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper 1/3 rd of the nose. It has a bimodal age distribution (10-20 and 50-60 years)

Clinical features:

  • Unilateral nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis 
  • Friable cherry-red, vascular polypoidal mass in the upper third of the nasal cavity

Investigation of choice is biopsy after appropriate imaging showing the extent of the tumor.

The tumor may be low grade with pseudorosettes or high grade with nuclear pleomorphism. Lymph node metastasis can occur in 10-15% cases.

Treatment is surgery which can be combined with preoperative chemotherapy or radiotherapy.

questions.text: A patient is planned for surgical resection of esthesioneuroblastoma. Which of the following statements is false about the same?

choices.text: Lymph node metastasis does not occur

questions.solution:
Lymph node metastasis occurs in 10-15% of the cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for osteomas?
questions.solution:
Osteomas are most commonly seen in the frontal sinus followed by ethmoid and maxillary sinuses.

They remain asymptomatic and are incidentally found on x-rays. Treatment is required only when they cause obstructive symptoms or pressure effects.

The image given shows the x-ray image of an osteoma in the frontal sinus.

questions.text: The most common site of occurrence of fibrous dysplasia is
questions.solution:
The maxilla is the most common site for fibrous dysplasia. 

Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture is replaced by vascularized fibrous tissue.

However, the difference between the two is as follows -

  Fibrous dysplasia Ossifying fibroma
Site More common in the maxilla.  More common in the mandible 
Radiology  No well-defined edge, lesion merges with surroundings  Well demarcated lesion
Pathology Strongly reactive for osteocalcin Weakly reactive for osteocalcin

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for ossifying fibroma?
questions.solution:
The mandible is the most common site for the occurrence of ossifying fibroma.

Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture is replaced by vascularized fibrous tissue.

However, the difference between the two is as follows -

questions.text: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of the face, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-defined expanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic of fibrous dysplasia.

In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillary sinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. 

It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye.

The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due to fibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. There is orbital displacement on the left side.

questions.text: Which of the following histological varieties is the most common among paranasal sinus carcinomas?
questions.solution: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Where is squamous cell carcinoma most commonly found in the paranasal sinuses?
questions.solution: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common in the maxillary sinuses followed in turn by ethmoids, frontal and sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: A carpenter was diagnosed with sinonasal carcinoma and planned for surgical resection. Which of the following histological varieties would be most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinoma is the most common variety in this case. Workers of the furniture industry or woodworkers develop adenocarcinoma.

It is most commonly found in the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity.

Workers engaged in nickel refining may develop squamous cell carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma.

Other early features include:

  • Nasal stuffiness
  • Facial paraesthesias 
  • Pain
  • Epiphora.

These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.

Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged.

Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit. 

Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumor spreads inferiorly.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is classified using Ohngren’s classification?
questions.solution:
Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma.

An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible.

Ohngren's line(below image):

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and diplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image to classify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
questions.solution:
Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case.

It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra.

questions.text: You have a patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes will be most commonly involved?
questions.solution:
The submandibular and jugulodigastric nodes are the most commonly involved in maxillary sinus carcinoma.

Maxillary and ethmoid sinus drain primarily into retropharyngeal nodes but, these nodes are inaccessible for palpation.

questions.text: In a known case of maxillary carcinoma, histopathology of the surgically resected region shows that the tumor has eroded into the floor and medial wall of the orbit and the frontal sinus. Which of the following is the best management strategy?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is preferred here, as in this case surgery has already been performed. The tumor staging is T4 by AJCC classification. 

T3 and T4 lesions are treated by combined modalities of radiation and surgery. Radiation in such cases may be given preoperatively or postoperatively.

T1 and T2 lesions without nodal or distant metastasis are treated with surgery or radiation with equal results.

Stage Description
T1 Tumour restricted to maxillary sinus mucosa
T2 Bony erosion - extension into hard palate or middle meatus, except posterior wall and pterygoid plates
T3 Invasion into suprastructures such as:
  • Posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Subcutaneous tissues
  • Floor or medial wall of orbit
  • Pterygoid fossa
  • Ethmoid sinus
T4a Tumour invades any of the following: 
  • Anterior orbital contents
  • The skin of the nose or cheek
  • Infratemporal fossa
  • Pterygoid plates
  • Cribriform plate
  • Sphenoid or frontal sinuses 
T4b Tumour invades any of the following: 
  • Orbital apex
  • Brain/dura
  • Middle cranial fossa
  • Nasopharynx
